meanings.def: used when the person or people being spoken to both cause and are affected by an action
examples: Have you hurt yourself?
You don't seem quite yourself today (= you do not seem well or do not seem as happy as usual).
Enjoy yourselves!

meanings.def: used to emphasize the fact that the person who is being spoken to is doing something
examples: Do it yourself—I don't have time.
You can try it out for yourselves.
You yourself are one of the chief offenders.

meanings.def: used instead of ‘you’ in order to sound polite or formal (although some people do not consider this use to be correct)
examples: We sell a lot of these to people like yourself.
‘And yourself,’ he replied, ‘How are you?’
Don't act sophisticated—just be yourself.
How long were you by yourself in the house?
I like being alone in the house.
I’m going to London by myself next week.
I want to finish this on my own (= without anyone’s help).
a lone jogger in the park
long, solitary walks
a lonely child
Sam was very lonely when he first moved to New York.
a lonely house
Are you sure you did this exercise by yourself?

meanings.def: for only you to have or use; not shared
examples: I'm going to be away next week so you'll have the office to yourself.
Don't act sophisticated—just be yourself.
How long were you by yourself in the house?
I like being alone in the house.
I’m going to London by myself next week.
I want to finish this on my own (= without anyone’s help).
a lone jogger in the park
long, solitary walks
a lonely child
Sam was very lonely when he first moved to New York.
a lonely house
Are you sure you did this exercise by yourself?

idioms.def: for only you to have or use; not shared
examples: I'm going to be away next week so you'll have the office to yourself.
